entity: Support to the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1540 (2004) on the non-proliferation of all weapons of mass destruction
entity_raw_name: 13.	Support to the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1540 (2004) on the non-proliferation of all weapons of mass destruction
source_file: A_80_6 (SECT. 3)_ADD.3_CLUSTER II_FASCICLE ADVANCE UNEDITED COPY FOR ACABQ.json

content.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The mission in support of the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1540 (2004) is responsible for the provision of substantive, administrative and logistical support to assist the Committee in achieving the aims of the resolution. The mandate derives from Council resolution 1540 (2004) and from its subsequent resolutions, including, most recently, 2663 (2022).

In line with resolution 2663 (2022), where the Security Council extended the Committee’s mandate until 30 November 2032, the mission assists interested Member States in their national implementation efforts through country-specific visits and dialogues, national round tables, workshops and peer reviews, with the objective of building capacity, facilitating technical assistance and identifying and disseminating effective practices for the implementation of resolution 1540 (2004). The mission further supports the activities of the Committee through the organization of regional and subregional workshops on the implementation of the resolution and through country-specific missions and activities, cooperation between international and regional bodies, and the facilitation of outreach and effective partnerships with civil society and the private sector.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to prevent non-State actors from developing, acquiring, manufacturing, possessing, transporting, transferring or using nuclear, chemical or biological weapons and their means of delivery.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the mission will:

(a)	Facilitate assistance to Member States, upon their request, which includes support for national reviews of the status of implementation of resolution 1540 (2004) and development of national implementation action plans, and capacity-building and awareness-raising activities for  the implementation of resolution 1540 (2004);

(b)	Promote regional cooperation on the implementation of resolution 1540 (2004) by conducting regional and subregional activities, including training for points of contact for resolution 1540 (2004), peer review, and outreach workshops;

(c)	Follow up on the 2022 comprehensive review of the status of implementation of resolution 1540 (2004), conduct activities to raise awareness and support implementation of the outcome of the review, and mobilize resources to effectively support the renewed mandate of the Committee.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Enhanced national capacity to implement resolution 1540 (2004);
(b)	An increased number of reports and national implementation action plans submitted to the Committee;
(c)	Increased awareness and visibility of resolution 1540 (2004) and the risks posed by non-State actors acquiring access to weapons of mass destruction and their means of delivery;
(d)	Increased cooperation among regional peers in implementing resolution 1540 (2004);
(e)	Successful implementation of the outcome of the 2022 comprehensive review of the status of implementation of resolution 1540 (2004).

With regard to cooperation with other entities, the mission cooperates with Governments, international, regional and subregional organizations and civil society organizations to raise awareness of the requirements of resolution 1540 (2004) and to facilitate assistance to Member States, upon their request, to build capacity and draft legislation to enhance the implementation of the resolution.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the mission works closely with other relevant United Nations entities, such as UNODC, the Office of Counter-Terrorism, the United Nations Interregional Crime and Justice Research Institute and IAEA. The mission also cooperates with the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1373 (2001) concerning counter-terrorism and its Executive Directorate, as well as the Security Council Committee pursuant to resolutions 1267 (1999), 1989 (2011) and 2253 (2015) concerning Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (Da’esh), Al-Qaida and associated individuals, groups, undertakings and entities, as well as the Analytical Support and Sanctions Monitoring Team supporting that Committee.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following assumptions:
(a)	The proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and their means of delivery to non-State actors remains a threat to international peace and security;
(b)	The political environment in the Security Council continues to enable the Committee to reach consensus on the implementation of planned activities;
(c)	Member States continue to cooperate with the Committee;
(d)	Member States will have the need for assistance to implement resolution 1540 (2004).
The mission integrates a gender perspective into its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate, and is guided by the gender policy of the Office for Disarmament Affairs.

The mission, in support of the Committee, promotes diversity and inclusion and ensures inclusive programming throughout its work, including the inclusion of disability perspectives and other reinforcing factors, such as gender and age. The mission promotes an inclusive work environment that enables all stakeholders to participate fully and effectively in disarmament forums and processes.
Programme performance in 2024
Strengthened Member States cooperation and engagement in effective assistance collaboration following the Open Briefing on resolution 1540 (2004)

In 2024, the mission successfully convened its first Open Briefing as mandated by resolution 2663 (2022). The briefing enhanced Member States’ awareness of and engagement in the Committee's activities, and facilitated cooperation and sharing of experiences in implementing the resolution.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 61).

Table 61 – Performance measure: Enhanced engagement of Member States in implementing resolution 1540 (2004), as demonstrated by increased information exchange and efforts to address identified needs following the Open Briefing

table_content.text: As mandated by resolution 2663 (2022), the Open Briefing for Member States and international, regional, and subregional organizations was successfully convened.

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Enhanced regional cooperation on implementing resolution 1540 (2004) – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the mission contributed to providing support to Member States by having conducted 9 regional workshops that promoted a regional approach towards the full implementation of resolution 1540 (2004). This exceeded the planned target of three workshops planned for 2024. These workshops contributed to the high-rate of points of contact appointments and engagement for resolution 1540 (2004) in promoting national implementation efforts.
Lessons learned and planned change

The mission learned that ensuring sustainable implementation requires national ownership and active participation at the national and regional levels. In applying the lesson, the mission will ensure an integrated approach to capacity-building efforts that align national priorities with the objectives of resolution 1540 (2004), expand its partnerships with regional organizations and entities to build synergies, and enhance mechanisms for continuous feedback for improvements of activities.
Expected progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure IV).
Figure IV – Performance measure: number of regional workshops that enhance Member States’ capacity to implement resolution 1540 (2004)

content.text: B.	Proposed post and non-post resource requirements for 2026

children.text: Resource requirements (regular budget) – Table 63 – Financial resources
(Thousands of United States dollars)
Table 64 – Human resources
a	Other level, unless otherwise stated.

The proposed resource requirements for the mission for 2026 amount to $3532,000 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for salaries and common staff costs ($959,100) for the continuation of six posts (1 P-5, 2 P-3 and 3 General Service (Other level)), and operational costs ($2,572,900) comprising expert fees ($1,991,800) and travel ($158,600) of the nine experts of the Committee, official travel of the members of the Committee and staff ($124,600), facilities and infrastructure ($228,200), communications and information technology ($55,200), and other supplies, services and equipment ($14,500).

For 2026, no change is proposed to the number and level of posts for the mission. A vacancy rate of zero per cent has been applied to the staff costs for international staff, while a rate of 33.3 per cent has been applied for national staff, on the basis of the actual vacancy rate in March 2025 and the average vacancy rate in 2024 respectively.

The increase in the requirements for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable primarily to the increased requirements for expert fees, lower vacancy rate for international staff compared with the rate of 6.7 per cent applied in 2025, and a new requirement for conference costs related to the 1540 Committee Open Consultations. The increase is offset in part by the application of a higher vacancy rate for national staff compared with the rate of 6.7 per cent applied in 2025 and the application of latest ICT standard rates.
Extrabudgetary resources

In 2025, extrabudgetary resources in the amount of $1,000,000 will be used for activities in support of the implementation of resolution 1540 (2004), including facilitation of the participation of Member States in events relating to the resolution and country-specific activities. The resources will also cover the continuous work of two Regional Coordinators (P-4) stationed in Africa and Asia, along with a Political Affairs Officer (P-3) responsible for project implementation globally.

In 2026, extrabudgetary resources in the amount of $1,000,000 are projected to be used to organize or support a number of activities relating to resolution 1540 (2004), including facilitation of the participation of Member States in events relating to the resolution and country-specific activities. The resources will also cover the continuous work of the two Regional Coordinators (P-4) and the Political Affairs Officer (P-3).
